IRM 10.8.6.3.7, IA-Identiﬁcation and Authentication - One (1) new control was added and name changed for IA-10 to align with NIST 800-53 Rev 5, updated section to align with Security Policy Boiler Plate.
IRM 10.8.6.3.8, IR-Incident Response - All controls were removed to align with NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5, section referred back to IRM 10.8.1 for guidance.
IRM 10.8.6.3.9, MA-Maintenance - One (1) new control was added to align with NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5 and section updated to align with Security Policy Boiler Plate.
IRM 10.8.6.3.11, PE-Physical and Environmental Protection - All controls were removed, section referred back to IRM 10.8.1 for guidance.
IRM 10.8.6.3.14, PT-Personally Identiﬁable Information Processing and Transparency - New control family added to align with NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5.

IRM 10.8.6.3.16, SA-System and Services Acquisition - Five (5) controls removed, two (2) controls added, and two (2) control names changed, reference was added to the Critical Software section of IRM 10.8.1.
IRM 10.8.6.16.3, SA-10 Developer Conﬁguration Management - Section number changed.
IRM 10.8.6.3.16.5, SA-15 Development Process, Standards, and Tools - Removed an outdated link to Secure Coding Standards.

IRM 10.8.6.3.17.14, SC-39 Process Isolation - Control number changed.

Section numbers changed where necessary to align with Security Policy Boiler Plate.

Exhibit 10.8.6-2, Security Requirements Checklists - Section title was updated and text was updated to align with Security Policy Boiler Plate and incorporate updates from DISA Application Security and Development STIG V5R1.
Exhibit 10.8.6-4, Recommended Best Practices - Removed and relocated from IRM 10.8.6 to IRM 2.5.3 Systems Development, Programming and Source Code.
Exhibit 10.8.6-5, Glossary and Acronyms - Added new acronyms or deﬁnitions.
Program details and organizational name changes were instituted due to Cybersecurity Policy Office realignment.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

IRM 10.8.6 dated July 21, 2020, is superseded. This IRM update supersedes all prior versions of IRM 10.8.6. This IRM supplements IRM 10.8.1, Information Technology (IT) Security Policy and Guidance and IRM 10.8.2, Information Technology Security Roles and Responsibilities .
AUDIENCE

IRM 10.8.6 shall be distributed to all personnel responsible for ensuring adequate security for developing, overseeing, managing, and implementing application security for IRS information and information systems. IRM is not intended as a primer for novice program developers/programmers. The reader is expected to be well-versed and experienced in general systems engineering, software development, and software testing practices. The reader should have a thorough understanding of technology involved in secure application development and in-depth experience with the development of software applications and web services. The Application Security and Development Policy will consist of, but will not be limited to, agency-deﬁned requirements, authoritative guidance, legislative mandates, and national standards. This policy applies to all employees, contractors, and vendors of the IRS.

) Overview: This Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) lays the foundation to implement and manage security controls and guidance for the use of applica- tions and application development within the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). a. This manual is subordinate to IRM
, Information Technology (IT) Security, Policy and Guidance , and augments the existing requirements identiﬁed within IRM
, as they relate to IRS applications and appli- cation development. (
) Purpose of the program: Development and publish policies to protect the against potential IT threats and vulnerabilities and ensure compliance with federal mandates and legislation. (

) Audience: The provisions in this manual apply to: a. All offices; including business, operating, and functional units within the IRS. b. Individuals and organizations having contractual arrangements with the IRS, including employees, contractors, vendors and outsourcing providers who: • Connect to an IRS network or system and/or • Operate information systems that store, process, or transmit IRS infor- mation and/or • Leverage automated programs (
) Policy Owner: Chief Information Officer (
) Program Owner: Cybersecurity Threat Response and Remediation (
) Program Goals: Cybersecurity Policy is responsible for the development and maintenance of IRS’s enterprise information technology security policies. The IRM

X Series provides the minimum security requirements to protect the conﬁdentiality, integrity, and availability of data processed on IRS systems. IRMs are developed in accordance with applicable laws, policies, federal regu- lations, Office of Management and Budget (OMB), Department of the Treasury Directives (TDs), National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) Publi- cations, and National Archives and Records Administration (NARA). (

) This IRM establishes comprehensive Information Technology (IT) security policies and provides guidance to all IRS organizations developing or modifying applications code for use within the IRS. This IRM shall be used in conjunction with coding guidelines found in: a. IRM
, Systems Development, Programming and Source Code Standards b. Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP) web site at https:// www.owasp.org/index.php/Main_Page (
) IRM
is part of the Security, Privacy and Assurance policy family; which consists of the IRM Part
series for IRS Information Technology Cybersecu- rity. Security and Development

Program Owner: Cybersecurity Threat Response and Remediation Program Goals: Cybersecurity Policy is responsible for the development and maintenance of IRS’s enterprise information technology security policies. The IRM

X Series provides the minimum security requirements to protect the conﬁdentiality, integrity, and availability of data processed on IRS systems. IRMs are developed in accordance with applicable laws, policies, federal regu- lations, Office of Management and Budget (OMB), Department of the Treasury Directives (TDs), National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) Publi- cations, and National Archives and Records Administration (NARA).
10.8 Information Technology (IT) Security

) This IRM applies to all IRS information and information systems, which include IRS production, development, test, and contractor systems. For information systems that store, process, or transmit classiﬁed national security information, refer to IRM
, Classiﬁed National Security Information (NSI) , for addi- tional procedures for protecting classiﬁed information. (

) The IRS shall ensure that: a. The product (e.g., software, hardware) and version selected are in accor- dance with IRS Enterprise Architecture (EA) Enterprise Standards Proﬁle (ESP) that dictates the official products and versions within the IRS; and b. The application or system version is a version for which the vendor still offers standardized technical support. (

) Security Requirements Checklists: a. Security Requirements Checklists (if accompanying this IRM) serve as the secure conﬁguration baseline and are developed in accordance with NIST Special Publication (SP)

, National Checklist Program for Products: Guidelines for Checklist Users and Developers . b. IRMs with accompanying checklists contain a checklist with general security requirements (e.g., Defense Information Systems Agency (DISA) Security Requirements Guide (SRG)), as well as checklists with platform or technology speciﬁc requirements (e.g., Security Technical Implementa- tion Guides (STIGs), Center for Internet Security (CIS) Benchmarks). In the event a checklist is not available for a speciﬁc platform or technology, the general requirements checklist shall be used. c. Security Requirements Checklists shall be used in addition to the require- ments within the IRM body. This allows for IRS and Department of the Treasury-deﬁned requirements contained within the IRM body to be captured in the secure conﬁguration baseline. d. In the event of a conﬂict between a checklist and the IRM body, the re- quirement(s) from the checklist shall be used. Note: The order of precedence only applies when there is a conﬂict between the IRM body and one of its accompanying checklists and does not apply when there is a discrepancy with IRM
e. Implementation of Security Requirements Checklists is required (CM-
). f. Refer to the Security Requirements Checklist exhibit for additional guidance. (
) In the event there is a discrepancy between this policy and IRM
, IRM
has precedence, unless the controls/requirements in this policy are more restrictive or otherwise noted. (

) This IRM establishes the minimum baseline security policy and requirements for all IRS IT assets in order to: a. Protect the critical infrastructure and assets of the IRS against attacks that exploit IRS assets. b. Prevent unauthorized access to IRS assets. c. Enable IRS IT computing environments that meet the security require- ments of this policy and support the business needs of the organization. (
) It is acceptable to conﬁgure settings to be more restrictive than those deﬁned in this policy. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) Authority (
) All IRS information systems and applications shall be compliant with Executive Orders (E.O.s), Office of Management and Budget (OMB), Federal Information Security Modernization Act of
(FISMA), National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), Department of Homeland Security (DHS), Department of the Treasury, and IRS guidelines as they apply.
) Acceptance and Risk-Based Decisions (
) Any exception to this policy requires the Authorizing Official (AO) to make a Risk-Based Decision (RBD). (
) Users shall submit RBD requests in accordance with IRM
and Cyberse- curity’s Security Risk Management (SRM) Risk Acceptance Process within the
To conﬁgure less restrictive requirements requires a risk-based decision. Refer to the Risk Acceptance and Risk-Based Decisions section within this IRM for additional guidance.

Users shall submit RBD requests in accordance with IRM 10.8.1 and Cyberse- curity’s Security Risk Management (SRM) Risk Acceptance Process within the Risk-Based Decision Standard Operating Procedures (SOP).
Refer to IRM 10.8.1 for additional guidance about risk acceptance.
